sub_topic: Prove that the intersection of two sets is a subset of each of the sets.
message_1: Let set A = {2, 4, 6, 8} and set B = {4, 6, 8, 10}. Show that the intersection of sets A and B is a subset of set A and set B.
message_2:
To show that the intersection of sets A and B is a subset of set A and set B, we first need to find the intersection of sets A and B. The intersection of two sets is the set of elements that are common to both sets.

Intersection of A and B, denoted as A ∩ B, contains the elements that are present in both set A and set B.

A ∩ B = {x | x ∈ A and x ∈ B}

Comparing the elements of set A and set B, we find that the common elements are 4, 6, and 8.

So, A ∩ B = {4, 6, 8}

Now, we need to show that A ∩ B is a subset of set A and set B.

A subset is a set whose elements are all members of another set. If all elements of set C are also elements of set D, then set C is a subset of set D, denoted as C ⊆ D.

To prove that A ∩ B is a subset of set A, we need to show that every element in A ∩ B is also an element of set A.

A ∩ B = {4, 6, 8} and set A = {2, 4, 6, 8}

Since all elements of A ∩ B are also elements of set A, we can conclude that A ∩ B ⊆ A.

Similarly, to prove that A ∩ B is a subset of set B, we need to show that every element in A ∩ B is also an element of set B.

A ∩ B = {4, 6, 8} and set B = {4, 6, 8, 10}

Since all elements of A ∩ B are also elements of set B, we can conclude that A ∩ B ⊆ B.

Thus, we have shown that the intersection of sets A and B, A ∩ B, is a subset of both set A and set B.
